ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HDB VOID DECKS
(Toilet facilities for senior citizens)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will consider providing toilet facilities and more tables and chairs in the void decks of HDB estates for the use of senior citizens.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    In new HDB estates, a kiosk with an attached toilet is provided to serve each precinct consisting of four to six blocks of flats. The toilet is manned and maintained by the kiosk operator who sells sundry items. It is a condition of the tenancy of such kiosks for the kiosk operator to open the toilet to the public for a fee. Residents can use such toilets. The HDB will not provide any other public toilets on the void deck because of maintenance problems.

    The HDB provides a Residents' Corner on the void deck of new apartment blocks. In each Residents' Corner, there is a partially enclosed space with a set of table and stools. Additional tables and stools can be provided if needed.

    In existing estates where there are no kiosks or Residents' Corners, the HDB can provide these facilities under the Repairs and Redecoration Programme.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, will the Minister of State consider asking the HDB to build kiosks in the existing estates so that such facilities can be provided?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have said in my main answer, HDB will consider such proposals.

LAND FOR NON-POLLUTIVE FARMING


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development what acreage of State land has been tendered out for non-pollutive farming activities as at the latest

Column: 278

convenient date and where, and how many more parcels and acreage of land will be tendered out.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, with the development of Agrotechnology Parks at Loyang, Tampines, Jalan Kayu, Nee Soon, Mandai, Sungei Tengah, Hong Kah, Murai, Ama Keng and Lim Chu Kang, about 1,500 hectares of land will be made available for non-pollutive farming. The land will be allocated in phases as and when the infrastructural works are completed. As at 31st December 1987, 40 plots of land at Sungei Tengah, Murai and Loyang totalling 137 hectares have been allocated by tenders for intensive high-tech farming.

    In addition, with the phasing out of pig farming in Jalan Kayu and Punggol, about 180 hectares of land will be available for short-term non-pollutive farming on three-year tenancy agreements. In these two areas, 49 plots totalling 60 hectares have been tendered out.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, could the Minister of State enlighten the House how successful has been the tendering of these plots of land for non-pollutive farming activities?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the tendering exercises, the response has been very good. Of the 40 plots that have been tendered out, 38 plots of land have been allocated to local farmers who have been successful in their bid and who have made plans to start up their farms. The other two plots have been tendered out to local companies who are interested in diversifying into agri-business.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, in this case, could the Minister of State indicate what main farming activity is being carried out?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, a variety of farming activities is allowed on these plots of land. They range from cultivation of vegetables and food crops to orchids and ornamental plants. There is even a tender for one plot of land to be used for aquarium fish, bird and dog breeding. Other uses include 10 plots of land that have been tendered out for turf production on a three-year tenancy agreement.

    The following question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong-

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGE AT ANG MO KIO AVENUE 6
(Provision of shelter)


    5. Mr Lau Ping Sum asked the Minister for National Development whether the pedestrian overhead bridge under construction at Ang Mo Kio Avenue 6 near the Yio Chu Kang Mass Rapid Transit station will be provided with shelter; and what will be the cost of providing such a shelter.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the Public Works Department's practice not to provide a covered overhead pedestrian bridge if it is not connected directly to buildings at both ends. The overhead pedestrian bridge under construction at Ang Mo Kio Avenue 6 near the Yio Chu Kang Mass Rapid Transit station is not connected to any building and will not therefore be provided cover.

    It would only make sense to provide a sheltered overhead pedestrian bridge if the bridge under construction is extended 70 metres to the Mass Rapid Transit station at one end and 20 metres to the nearest HDB flat (Block 636) at the other. Such a covered overhead pedestrian bridge will cost $422,000 as against the bridge under construction which will cost $238,000.

     Mr Lau Ping Sum (Yio Chu Kang): Sir, would the Minister of State consider in the longer-term, in order to upgrade the quality of life and to provide greater convenience to residents, to review this policy of providing shelter to all overhead pedestrian bridges?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, PWD constantly re-assesses its designs for overhead pedestrian bridges. If there is a need and if it is cost-beneficial to improve the design and provide cover, then it would be considered.

COMMUNITY HOSPITAL IN SERANGOON NEW TOWN


    6. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Acting Minister for Health whether his Ministry will consider building a community hospital in Serangoon New Town.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, there are no plans at present to build a community hospital in Serangoon New Town.

    As I had stated in this House on 25th March 1986, my Ministry plans to build two community hospitals during the next 6 to 7 years. The first community hospital will be built in Ang Mo Kio New Town.

    As the concept of a community hospital is a new one, my Ministry would like to review the position after the initial years of operation before building the second in the early 1990s. The exact location has not been decided yet.

PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [11th January, 1988],

    "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question again proposed.
11.10 am

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I proceed any further, I want to state categorically that I fully and wholeheartedly support the institutionalization of multi-racial representation in our Parliament, and this is also the stand of my other Malay colleagues in this House. I may have reservations about the way we go about achieving this very noble objective.

    Sir, in moving the Parliamentary Elections (Amendment) Bill at yesterday's sitting of this House, the First Deputy Prime Minister read part of the letter I wrote him on 30th September 1982 where I had raised strong objections to the "Twin Constituencies" concept under which a Malay candidate from one constituency and a non-Malay candidate from another, probably a Chinese, would have to stand in a General Elections as a pair. The First

Column: 282

Deputy Prime Minister has also disclosed the reasons for my objections and I do not therefore intend to repeat them today.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I still have reservations abot the GRC proposal. Members of the GRC teams do not even have constituencies of their own to look after. They all belong to what I term "super constituencies", each of which is about three times the size of a single-member constituency. Mr Speaker, Sir, but what moved me to support the GRC proposal was the voting trend in the 1984 General Elections and, frankly, Sir, by what took place in Chong Boon as described by the First Deputy Prime Minister yesterday.

    As I have stressed earlier, I still have reservations about the GRC proposal. But do I have a better alternative that will overcome the trend where voters pick candidates according to their personal attributes and ignore the basic need for a racially-balanced slate of candidates in Parliament? The answer, Mr Speaker, Sir, is no. I do not have a better alternative.

    It took Cabinet almost four years to finally come up with the GRC proposal. It is the best means we can think of. The public had a year or so to discuss and debate the Team MP concept at forums organized for the National Agenda or at other similar forums. Yet to this day, Sir, no one or group has a better alternative to offer. But the doors are not closed, Sir. The Government is still open to suggestions - good suggestions, of course. But until a better proposal can be thought out, the GRC formula will at least ensure that our Parliament will be multi-racial in composition, irrespective of whether the PAP rules Singapore or not.

    Of course, Sir, one way of ensuring Malay presence in Parliament is to assign constituencies for Malays only where only Malay candidates can stand in General Elections. But let us ask ourselves, Sir: Will this be fair to the non-Malays in these constituencies? Should they be compelled to choose their representatives in Parliament from among candidates from a particular race? The answer is obvious, Sir.

    Another way of ensuring Malay presence in Parliament, Sir, is the PKMS way where Malays elect Malays to represent

Column: 283

Malays in Parliament. But where do we go from here? Very soon, chauvinistic Chinese political parties will also demand that Chinese elect Chinese to represent Chinese interests in Parliament, and likewise, chauvinistic Indian political parties. Will this do us good in the long term? Will this do Singapore good in the long run? I leave it to the good and rational judgment of my fellow Singaporeans to decide.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Geylang Serai): Mr Speaker, Sir, let me also say at the outset that I give my full support to this Bill. I am very glad that the First Deputy Prime Minister is referring this Bill to a Select Committee. Our citizens must be given the full opportunity to clearly understand the reasons for this Bill. I believe that in the initial stages of the discussions there might have been some confusion because there was the confusion of the town council concept and the Team MP or the GRC concept. These have clouded their thinking. Because of this, they may not have fully grasped the issues, and the fundamental reasons why we have proposed the GRC concept.

    The First Deputy Prime Minister in moving this Bill has outlined clearly the development as far back as 1982 and also the exhaustive thinking which has gone into this very important and very critical issue, before this proposal is tabled in Parliament for debate and for acceptance. My colleagues, PAP MPs, and also the Opposition, the Member for Potong Pasir, have given their views. I think the citizens must closely reflect on what has been said yesterday and again today. With the Bill before the the Select Committee, they will have a chance to give their views and also to bring up, if they have, a better solution to this issue or to this problem.

    The Member for Potong Pasir in opposing this Bill said that this Bill will introduce communalism and racialism in the electoral system, that the Bill will enshrine communalism in our laws. This will, he said, undermine nation building. Is this really so? Will provisions to enable adequate Malay and other minority representation in Parliament lead to more communalism? Will the proposal to ensure

Column: 284

that political parties, which want to form the Government and to lead the country, adopt a moderate multi-racial approach lead to more communalism? The First Deputy Prime Minister and the other PAP MPs have given ample examples, both external as well as internal, to show how, in politics, race and religious issues feature prominently.They have drawn examples from countries like Fiji, Sri Lanka and Lebanon, and so on.

    Can a one-man-one-vote system in a multi-racial society ensure that racial and religious issues will not be used to win votes? We cannot take our present racial harmony for granted. We must therefore, as responsible leaders, take steps as soon as we recognize this danger to institutionalize safeguards and checks in our system to ensure that Parliament will always be multi-racial and that political parties take a moderate, middle-ground multi-racial approach. Without these checks and safeguards in a one-man-one-vote system in a multi-racial society, we will, if we are not careful, allow a situation to develop which can have very disastrous results.

    I think all right-thinking Singaporeans, all responsible Singaporeans, accept and believe in multi-racialism and that we must practise moderation in politics. Minority races must be given opportunities to have their views represented in Parliament, their aspirations reflected and thought about in legislations and government policies. We should not therefore wait for problems to appear before we start thinking about introducing safeguards to ensure long-term stability and racial harmony. We should face the facts. It is painful but we should face the fact that the practice of democracy in a one-man-one-vote system in a multi-racial society has its dangers. We should not take a chance and later see our children suffer. Their lives, their way of living, these would be affected if we do not make adequate safeguards when we are able to do so.

    When the twin constituency idea was first discussed in 1982, and this has been mentioned again by Dr Ahmad Mattar, Member for Brickworks, Minister for the Environment, the Malay MPs, rejected the idea. We felt the proposal was an affront.

Column: 285

When other constituencies would have only one MP, why was there a need for some constituencies to have two MPs, so that the Malay MP could lean on a bigger brother? However, we recognized that there was this problem of ensuring multi-racial representation in Parliament. And we are glad that the other leaders saw the problem in the same perspective that we did, and began an exhaustive search for a better alternative system.

    As a Malay MP, it is necessary for me not only to understand the problem on a personal basis but also to take into account the national interest. I have to consider the position on a personal basis: would I like to stand under such a system? After all, when I first stood for election in the 1980 elections, I stood against a Chinese candidate, the General Secretary of the Singapore United Front, and I was returned with a majority of 72% of the valid votes. I understand that perhaps for the time being this problem will not arise. But what about the future? Can future Malay MPs be as successful when developments and voting trends in 1984 have shown that there are real dangers. Must I be that proud, be that egoistic, to say that since I can win, why have this new system and in the process bring abouta problem for future Malay candidates who want to stand for elections to Parliament? After considerable thinking, reviewing, self-examination, soul-searching, I have to accept that we must have a safeguard. And to me, after exhaustive thinking and discussions, the GRC concept, imperfect as it may be, is perhaps the best solution that we have before us today.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I get a clarification from the Member?

     Mr Speaker: On what? You have not said anything today.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: On what he has said.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Can I leave him to ask it when I have finished?

     Mr Speaker: Please sit down, Mr Chiam. He is not giving way.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am sorry.

Column: 286



     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: No. He can speak later.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: No, I want a clarification.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: You can speak after I have finished.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: After you have spoken?

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: Yes, after I have spoken, provided you get the permission of Mr Speaker. I am not in a position to allow you to speak.

    As I said, it may not be a perfect solution and other MPs have pointed out the dangers. But I am prepared to accept that for the time being, as the search continues, we accept the solution of the GRC.

    The Member for Siglap has mentioned the problems and the arduous task which Malay MPs have of balancing the minority interests with the national interests. We cannot afford to be looked upon as a communal MP. And I agree with him - that it would be political suicide for us to be so identified. So as the Bill provides for these safeguards, I support the Bill and I would urge every Singaporean to carefully consider the reasons for the Bill and to give it their full support.

    Before I end, I would just like to touch on a technical aspect of the Bill, namely, the definition of "person belonging to the Malay community". I agree with the points made by the Member for Tanah Merah regarding the characteristics of persons who belong to the Malay community. I feel that such persons should consider themselves as Malays, have an interest in the welfare and the wellbeing of the Malays; they should feel Malay and those who fall within this category should be allowed to contest in the elections as a Malay. Reading the definition which mentions certain racial groups like Javanese, Boyanese, Bugis, and Arab, although there is a general clause covering "any other person", some of my Indian Muslim friends have asked me, "Will they be considered as Malays?" After all, they feel that they belong to the Malay community, and they have a genuine interest in the welfare and the wellbeing of the Malay community. Would they, under the definition so

Column: 287

provided, be considered as Malays? I think these are issues which are important and which, I think,should be discussed further when the Bill is in Select Committee.

    Another point which 1DPM mentioned is the small talent pool of Malays and the difficulty in getting good Malay candidates. I believe that if the definition is made flexible, it can help enlarge the pool, and in this process those who feel themselves as Malays, those who consider themselves as Malays, can come out to help serve and look after the interests of the Malay community.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification.

     Mr Speaker: On what point, Mr Chiam?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Clarification from the Member.

     Mr Speaker: You want to clarify his points?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes, on what he has said. Just to clarify one point. He has said that for the time being he accepts the solution of the GRC. I want to clarify with him whether or not he is conceding that in future elections, he will not get elected on his own steam.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: No. I think I have told the House very clearly that when I first stood for election in a single member constituency against a Chinese candidate, who was then the Secretary-General of the SUF, a political leader who had more political experience at that time than I have (because he had stood unsuccessfully in many other elections), I had managed to defeat him. And I do not think that the incumbents have a problem, and I think 1DPM has said that the incumbent Malay MPs will not have a problem now but new Malay candidates may be vulnerable because of the voting trends as we have seen in 1984. And also there is ample evidence, as I mentioned earlier, to show developmentsof this nature in other countries.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, I rise to speak in full support of the amendment Bill moved by the First Deputy Prime Minister.

Column: 288



    I will come straight to the point. I am surprised that the Member for Potong Pasir did not answer the Hon. First Deputy Prime Minister's point when he took part in the debate and delivered his speech yesterday. The point is this. The SDP's constitution does not state that it subscribes to a multi-racial Singapore. Sir, may I ask him whether this is an oversight? If it is, whether he and the SDP intend to amend it accordingly? Because he himself said that he is all for a multi-racial Singapore.

    Furthermore, he portrays himself as a champion of the Malays. Here I would like to ask him again whether the Presidential Council for Minority Rights has now become redundant. And also according to him, since Article 152 of the Constitution is pernicious, would he move that it be repealed? If not, how can he fallaciously believe and subscribe to a multi-racial Singapore, in his own description, "one people, one race, out of mixed marriages, mixed religions"? I think this House would like to be enlightened on this, and I hope, Mr Speaker, Sir, you will be so kind enough as to enable the Member for Potong Pasir to make his clarifications.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: May I, Mr Speaker, Sir, be allowed to make the clarification?

     Mr Speaker: Clarification on Mr Ng's remarks?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Yes.

     Mr Speaker: All right.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Perhaps Mr Ng, a very old member of the PAP, will recall that -

     An hon. Member: Member for Punggol.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am saying that he is an old member of the PAP. He will recall that, in fact, the first constitution of the PAP did not include this clause on multi-racialism in Singapore. It was an afterthought.

    The SDP has no apologies to make in regard to its constitution. We subscribe to democratic socialism. And Mr Ng who, I believe, is also a socialist will understand that the term "socialist" also includes the belief that there must be multi-racialism. That is the reason.

Column: 289



     Mr Chandra Das: This is a new one!

     Mr Chiam See Tong: As regards the Presidential Council for Minority Rights, since he has brought up this point, I shall be pointing out later in the debate on the amendment to the Constitution that there are provisions to exclude this GRC concept from the provisions in the Constitution which relate to the Presidential Council.

    I do not think Article 152 of the Constitution is pernicious in any way. In fact, the Prime Minister himself has guaranteed the Malays of their special privileges. So is the Member for Punggol saying that the Prime Minister was wrong?

    As regards mixed marriages, I do not see why Mr Ng is against it. I am all for it. Member for Punggol, what is wrong with mixed marriages? Is he against it? Let me know, please.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am a bit surprised that once again he has totally digressed, hoping that by his roundabout answers he actually need not answer the questions I posed.

    First, in the constitution of the SDP, it is not stated that it subscribes to a multi-racial Singapore. That has been pointed out to him. All I am asking is: is that an oversight? If it is, would the Member for Potong Pasir and the SDP amend the constitution of the SDP? He has not fully answered that. Instead he has gone on to describe that I am a socialist and what socialism is all about.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: You should know it.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: I am a democratic socialist. The Russians call themselves socialists too. So do the Chinese. But I would not allow myself to be drawn aside. So I come straight to the point. Point (1), he has not fully answered the question. Point (2), he portrays himself as the champion of the Malays. Article 152 of the Constitution makes it pernicious according to him, and he has asked me to rebut. No, he has to answer that because he has put it that way. In fact, yesterday, when he had the Floor, he asked all the PAP MPs to come out and speak up on how they feel. He has got it. But in my own way, I would not allow him to take the Floor and have

Column: 290

his say, so as to mislead and beguile the people. I do not think I can allow that, Sir. Point (3) Sir, that explanation or by his remarks, make it appear that the Presidential Council on Minority Rights is redundant. Then why would he not move an amendment that it be repealed?

    On mixed marriages, I have got nothing against it because all these are personal matters. There is such a thing as privacy. But we have to respect people's feelings. I say how can he so fallaciously believe that by entering into mixed marriages we can have one race, one people. Who is he talking to? The people of Singapore are not foolish enough or gullible enough to believe him. He has said it. That is his definition of multi-racialism. That is his interpretation of what a multi-racial Singapore is. Far from it.

    Sir, I hope he will address himself to the questions that I posed and not try to sidetrack.

     The Leader of the House (Mr Wong Kan Seng): May I make two points, Mr Speaker, Sir? When Members address the House, could they please confine themselves to the titles or the constituencies which Members belong to, instead of calling "Mr Chiam" or "Mr Ng"? That is one point. The other point is that when a Member speaks, the whole House should be silent according to the Standing Orders.
